channel.name: Can't evaluate prover code outside an as_prover block during Contract.compile()

messages.content:
What may cause this error when attempting to compile my contract?

I don't get this error when trying to compile an empty contract like `class Test extends SmartContract {}`.

```
    thrown: Array [
      0,
      Array [
        248,
        MlBytes {
          "c": "Jsoo_runtime.Error.Exn",
          "l": 22,
          "t": 0,
        },
        237,
      ],
      [Error: Can't evaluate prover code outside an as_prover block],
    ]
```

i'm compiling my app now with:
```
Circuit.asProver(() => {Contract.compile()})
```

(+ wrapped in a promise) and its taking a serious while, does asProver impact performance of compile? or what is it meant for?

What version of `SnarkyJS `are you using? Using `Circuit.asProver` is a way to run something in your circuit function without it being included in the proof.  It will only run on the prover side, but not be visible to the verifier.

0.9.2, our problem was running MerkleMap code inside a circuit, even tho it was unrelated to the circuit and did not need to be proven. We've ended up creating an empty circuit witness to work around this problem, but i can try using Circuit.asProver as well as it sounds like something made for the exact same problem.
do NOT put constraints inside asProver though -- asProver won't contribute to the circuit
yes wrapping compile in asProver as an act of despair on my side 😄
the worst part is as you can see in the stack trace its already wrapper under .asProver
How does it behave without Circuit.log? Just doing console.log(publicKey.toBase58())? This should work in a witness block, but maybe the logic in the this.address getter is flawed
its the this.address that is flawed because i put the logs there to understand whats going on internally
however i did not manage to replicate the same issue in a standalone / fresh contract

Just for context: the 'malformed' field elements which look like { value: [1, number] } are how SnarkyJS represents variables.
So it would be expected to log something like this (with console.log) inside a method. But not outside a method / transaction, there you shouldn't get variables obviously. And in a method, inside Circuit.witness the expectation would be that something like toBase58 could successfully read out the variable and turn it into a base 58 string
By the way, Circuit.witness and Circuit.asProver are no-ops outside a method. They just run the function normally
yeah i thought so and built my code with this in mind ^^
shall i prepare a full reproduction in my repo, for you to take a look at when you have time later?
Yes please!
Actually, reproducing it outside your repo in a simple environment would be better
i tried but couldnt pinpoint the right set of conditions for it to happen

@maht0rz and @gregor - I ran into the same issue and I'm working on wrapping my compile in an `asProver`.  But I'd also like to save the vk to a file.  `Circuit.asProver` returns void, so is there a way to access the vk after compiling a zkprogram in an as prover block?
YourContract._verificationKey i think
or smtn like that - best to inspect the SmartContract typings to find out
Matej, do you have zk programs working in a test suite that I could peep?
I have some files that I can run, but I'm working on converting those to actual behavior tests.  I want to make sure I avoid pitfalls while running within a test.
Can you show the code that’s causing the error?
I don’t think wrapping the compiler in an asProver is the way
Yeah, it doesn't feel rightl

@Florian https://github.com/trumpet-zk-ignite-1/Contracts/blob/25febd28f711c35646938a7baabcaeee662b6577/src/phase/PhaseProof.ts

Here is my proof

messages.content: On line 44, are you trying to call a function of the public input ? 🤔
Is that not allowed?  My public input is a struct.  I put all of the logic of my proof branched in functions on the struct because I thought the code was cleaner.

So a `PhaseState` has the functions `applyMove` which knows how to transition the phase state from A to B, and the proof just checks that the the new public input is indeed the old public input with the move applied.
I am actually unsure about that but I wouldn’t be surprised if that causes issues - could you try putting that function into a standalone one like applyMove(publicData)
Or maybe something in there is broken, separately?
I can try changing the public input to a `Field` and just hash my state down to a field to accomplish the same thing, with more steps.  I'll let you know if that helps
Something can always just be broken 🙂
You can still have a composite data structure as an input, that shouldn’t be a problem
Where would you suggest to define the new function?  Just in like `src/helpers/applyMove.ts` or something like that?
You could also define it right inside where the ZkProgeam is or where you input structure lies

https://github.com/trumpet-zk-ignite-1/Contracts/blob/18a789f2509a3ceb813af238b3ec4db03367eccb/src/phase/PhaseProof.ts

messages.content:
please forget `asProver` as a catch-all way to fight `can't evaluate prover code..` errors.
as I said above, `asProver` when called outside provable code is a no-op. It does nothing.

I'm glad you found the issue @45930. It's a very common error: Trying to read out values of field elements in provable code - not possible.
So this:
```ts
return rowIdx.add(this.x).toBigint();
```
is wrong because you use `.toBigInt()` as part of provable code. (more context here: https://github.com/o1-labs/snarkyjs/issues/224)

The error message (`Can't evaluate prover code...`) is arguably very confusing, and making it better is one of the next tasks we've planned to do.

It’s one thing to know the rule, but yeah, when it hits the error it doesn’t reference a line number or say anything about calling “toBigInt”.  And when you’re writing the code, there’s no IDE hint that says anything is wrong.

If there was a decorator to use with struct functions such that the developer is explicitly saying “I want this function to be usable in a circuit”, then could eslint just warn us as the mistake is being written?
I'd love to have such an eslint rule
Doesn't the stack trace point you to `toBigInt()`?

@gregor You know, it's possible that it is if I use the long stack trace option.  But no, when I asked the question here, I wasn't being pointed to `toBigInt()` - otherwise I would have seen the issue.

I got this error in a test where I first compile the program, then execute a function on it.  The error was in `.compile()`, and I had no idea where the issue was, so I had to dig through all my code to find the issue.  This is a rule I _know_ about, but I just got sloppy or wasn't thinking at the time.  I also wrote functions like `toJSON()` which do not run in the prover.  If I could be more explicit when I define a new function about where it should be used, and then get linting capabilities, that would be epic 👌

Btw, we have some major improvements to the stack traces coming up - they will be pruned of all kinds of unnecessary shit and will be much shorter, so I hope that they become more helpful.

Still agree with the linting ideas. This might even be possible without any annotation - we already have `@method` / Zkprogram methods, and in the eslint plugin we can start from there and find all the code that's used inside one of them
but maybe still better to have an annotation
